testimony.name: Pablo Zevallos
key_points: New York City is experiencing a severe housing shortage, particularly for affordable housing
The shortage disproportionately affects low-income households and contributes to segregation
City of Yes for Housing Opportunity will facilitate increased construction of affordable housing
The policy will combat exclusionary zoning practices
Legalizing EDUs (Efficient Dwelling Units) offers various benefits, including intergenerational wealth and aging in place
Lifting restrictions on SROs (Single Room Occupancy) would help provide permanent housing opportunities
Transit-oriented development and town center zoning would add needed 'missing middle' housing
Ending required parking mandates would remove barriers to housing goals
The amendments would make affordable housing more widely available across communities
Passing these amendments would set a precedent for future city governments to address the housing crisis

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: The policy is contained within city of yes for housing opportunity, but facilitate increased construction for affordable housing and combat during exclusionary zoning practices, enacting UAP with income averaging and making the deep affordability, NIH option independently available to DCP would offer lower income households greater housing opportunities, particularly in well resourced neighborhoods throughout the city.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote directly mentions UAP (Universal Affordability Preference) and discusses how it would facilitate the construction of affordable housing and provide greater housing opportunities for lower-income households in well-resourced neighborhoods, which aligns with the proposal's goal.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: Lifting restrictions on building SROs would help provide permanent housing opportunities, particularly for supportive housing.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: While not explicitly mentioning residential conversions, this quote discusses lifting restrictions on Single Room Occupancy (SRO) buildings, which is related to the concept of converting non-residential spaces into housing opportunities, aligning with the residential conversions element of the proposal.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: New measures like transit oriented development and town center zoning would add badly needed missing middle housing.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote directly mentions town center zoning as one of the new measures that would add needed 'missing middle housing', which aligns with the proposal's goal of creating more housing in commercial corridors and building vibrant mixed-use neighborhoods.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: And ending required parking mandates would remove spatial and cost barriers to these goals.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote directly addresses the removal of parking mandates, highlighting how it would remove spatial and cost barriers, which aligns with the proposal's goal of ending parking mandates to increase housing production and lower costs.
